core_principles.title: The Reverse Principle
core_principles.description: In ALS, using support does NOT make you dependent. It's the REVERSE. The less fatigue we give to the body, the better we are dealing with MND/ALS. Early support PRESERVES strength.

core_principles.title: Being Practical vs Being Positive
core_principles.description: It is good to stay positive and hope your PALS may never need BiPAP or feeding tube. But sometimes this positivity becomes a delusion, and we avoid being practical. No doctor will tell you 'now is the right time' - YOU as CALS need to be practical and recognize the signs.

core_principles.title: The CO‚ÇÇ Problem - Why SpO‚ÇÇ is Misleading
core_principles.description: In ALS, the problem is NOT getting oxygen in - it's getting CO‚ÇÇ out. Weakened diaphragm muscles prevent proper exhalation. SpO‚ÇÇ readings can be misleading because CO‚ÇÇ retention doesn't show up initially. Your PALS can have SpO‚ÇÇ at 96% and still desperately need BiPAP.

core_principles.title: The Hindsight Perspective
core_principles.description: Those whose PALS are already on BiPAP and feeding tubes see the WHOLE picture. They wish they had started earlier. They see how early use could have prevented emergencies, preserved more muscle strength, and given more quality time.

key_principles: Early BiPAP can delay tracheostomy by 6 months to 2+ years
Early PEG prevents emergency situations where both PEG and tracheostomy are needed together
Normal SpO‚ÇÇ readings can hide dangerous CO‚ÇÇ buildup in ALS patients
No doctor will tell you 'now is the right time' - you must recognize the signs yourself
In ALS, less fatigue = slower progression. Using support is smart, not giving up
Emergency interventions are traumatic and riskier than planned ones - anticipate, don't react

questions.question: When does a PALS typically need BiPAP and why shouldn't I wait for the doctor to tell me?
questions.answer:
The Practical Reality No One Tells You:

There is NO doctor who will tell you 'now is the right time to start BiPAP.' YOU as CALS must be practical and recognize the signs yourself.

Why Doctors Often Delay:

  • Many doctors unfamiliar with MND look only at SpO‚ÇÇ levels
  • If SpO‚ÇÇ is above 95%, they say 'no need for BiPAP'
  • They don't understand that CO‚ÇÇ retention is the real problem
  • CO‚ÇÇ builds up BEFORE SpO‚ÇÇ drops

The Core Warning Signs (Act Before SpO‚ÇÇ Drops):

  1. Morning headaches - CO‚ÇÇ built up overnight
  2. Cannot lie flat - needs pillows or recliner
  3. Excessive daytime tiredness despite sleeping
  4. Shallow breathing - short sentences, frequent pauses
  5. Weak cough - cannot clear throat properly
  6. Yawning frequently - body trying to get more oxygen

The SpO‚ÇÇ Trap: Even if SpO‚ÇÇ is 96%, if muscles are weak and showing above signs, BiPAP is needed. SpO‚ÇÇ can look normal while CO‚ÇÇ reaches dangerous levels. Don't fall into this trap!

üí¨ From a CALS Who Learned the Hard Way:
'We didn't have BiPAP at home and rushed to hospital in peak winter - tracheostomy done. If we had started BiPAP when signs appeared, we could have avoided this emergency.'

üáÆüá≥ Cost in India:
BiPAP Rental: ‚Çπ2,000-3,000/month
Purchase: ‚Çπ40,000-80,000
This investment can delay tracheostomy by 6 months to 2 years
questions.warning: Don't wait for SpO‚ÇÇ to drop below 90% - by then muscles are severely weakened. Act on early signs.
questions.recommendation: Keep BiPAP machine at home BEFORE you need it. Rental first to try, then buy. Having it ready reduces emergency hospital visits.
perspectives: We were on the other side of the picture and made the same mistake. Things look easy when reading these messages, but when you're living it, you're sometimes over-positive.
Early BiPAP is not giving up. It's being smart about preserving what we have.

questions.question: Can early BiPAP really delay tracheostomy? By how much?
questions.answer:
YES - early BiPAP can significantly delay tracheostomy, and this is one of the most important reasons to start early!

What Early BiPAP Does:

  • Reduces fatigue on diaphragm muscles
  • Less fatigue = slower muscle deterioration
  • Muscles stay functional longer
  • Emergency situations are prevented

Real Data from Community Experience:

  • Early BiPAP users: Delayed tracheostomy by 6 months to 2+ years
  • Late BiPAP users: Many had emergency/unplanned tracheostomy
  • Some PALS using BiPAP early are still on it years later!

The Emergency Scenario (What Happens When You Delay):

  1. PALS shows signs but SpO‚ÇÇ looks okay
  2. Family waits, thinking 'we'll start when needed'
  3. Diaphragm muscles silently weaken
  4. Sudden respiratory crisis during night
  5. Emergency hospital admission
  6. ICU admission, sometimes unplanned tracheostomy
  7. Recovery harder, family traumatized, PALS loses independence

The Planned Approach (What Should Happen):

  1. Start BiPAP at FIRST warning signs
  2. Use during sleep initially (when CO‚ÇÇ builds most)
  3. Gradually increase use as needed
  4. Muscles stay stronger longer
  5. If tracheostomy eventually needed, it's PLANNED
  6. Family has time to prepare practically and emotionally
üí° Community Message:
'Early BiPAP is not giving up. It's being smart about preserving what we have. Every month we delay tracheostomy is a month of easier care, more normalcy, more quality time.'

questions.question: What is the difference between oxygen and BiPAP for ALS patients?
questions.answer:
CRITICAL: They Are NOT the Same!

AspectOxygen OnlyBiPAP
Increases O‚ÇÇ in blood‚úÖ Yes‚úÖ Yes
Removes CO‚ÇÇ from blood‚ùå NO‚úÖ YES
Supports weak breathing muscles‚ùå NO‚úÖ YES
Safe for ALS when used alone‚ö†Ô∏è RISKY‚úÖ RECOMMENDED

Why This Matters in ALS:

In ALS, the diaphragm muscle weakens. The problem is NOT that lungs can't absorb oxygen - the problem is:

  1. Weak muscles can't push air OUT properly
  2. CO‚ÇÇ (carbon dioxide) gets trapped in the blood
  3. CO‚ÇÇ builds up to dangerous levels
  4. But SpO‚ÇÇ (oxygen saturation) can still look NORMAL

The Oxygen Alone Danger:

  • Oxygen makes SpO‚ÇÇ reading look good (95%+)
  • CO‚ÇÇ continues building up silently
  • Family thinks everything is fine
  • But CO‚ÇÇ retention causes headaches, confusion, eventually crisis
  • This gives FALSE reassurance

How BiPAP Works Differently:

  • IPAP (Inspiratory Pressure): Pushes air IN when breathing in
  • EPAP (Expiratory Pressure): Helps push CO‚ÇÇ OUT when breathing out
  • Supports the tired diaphragm
  • Prevents muscle exhaustion
  • Addresses BOTH oxygen and CO‚ÇÇ

Rule of Thumb: For ALS/MND with breathing difficulty: BiPAP is almost always better than oxygen alone. Consult a pulmonologist familiar with ALS.

questions.question: When Is Tracheostomy Needed? What are the decision criteria?
questions.answer:
Community experience shows tracheostomy is needed in two scenarios:

Scenario 1: Planned Tracheostomy (Preferred Path)

This is when you have time to prepare and plan properly. Tracheostomy becomes necessary when ALL of these are true:

  • ‚úÖ PALS is 24x7 dependent on BiPAP (not just nighttime use)
  • ‚úÖ The normal airway (nose/throat) has become too weak
  • ‚úÖ PALS is unable to maintain SpO‚ÇÇ even with BiPAP (SpO‚ÇÇ dropping below 90)
  • ‚úÖ ABG (Arterial Blood Gas) shows high CO‚ÇÇ despite BiPAP support
  • ‚úÖ Unable to clear secretions from lungs, leading to frequent chest congestion and infections

"Tracheostomy need arises when PALS become 24x7 dependent on BiPAP, the normal airway nose/throat has become weaker, plus they are unable to maintain saturation even with BiPAP ‚Äî then tracheostomy is a must."

"Tracheostomy is not an easy decision. Kindly understand the requirements and process and future care protocol, discuss with family members."

Scenario 2: Emergency Tracheostomy (Try to Avoid This!)

This happens when there is no time to plan. Emergency tracheostomy occurs when:

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è PALS gets pneumonia that is not properly managed
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è There is a sudden drop in oxygen saturation due to severe infection
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è There is no time ‚Äî doctors must intubate and perform emergency tracheostomy

üìã Decision Matrix

Use this simple guide to understand your situation:

IF...THEN...
PALS uses BiPAP only at night + maintains good SpO‚ÇÇ during dayContinue monitoring ‚Äî not ready for tracheostomy yet
PALS requires BiPAP 24x7 + still struggling to maintain SpO‚ÇÇThis is your time to act ‚Äî plan tracheostomy proactively
Frequent pneumonia + BiPAP becoming insufficientUrgent discussion needed ‚Äî don't wait for emergency
PALS already intubated in ICUTracheostomy is safest option after intubation

üìù Quick Summary

QuestionAnswer
Can we avoid tracheostomy?Many PALS continue on NIV BiPAP for years. Use cough assist, proper secretion management, and good care.
When is it definitely needed?24x7 BiPAP dependency + still unable to maintain SpO‚ÇÇ + weak airway
What is the preferred path?Planned tracheostomy (gives time to prepare) ‚Äî avoid emergency situations
Who should decide?You, your family, and PALS together, after consulting experienced caregivers and doctors
What if we're not ready?Talk to experienced group members, prepare knowledge-wise, and make an informed decision

if_then.if: PALS uses BiPAP only at night + maintains good SpO‚ÇÇ during day
if_then.then: Continue monitoring ‚Äî not ready for tracheostomy yet

if_then.if: PALS requires BiPAP 24x7 + still struggling to maintain SpO‚ÇÇ
if_then.then: This is your time to act ‚Äî plan tracheostomy proactively
Urgent discussion needed ‚Äî don't wait for emergency
Tracheostomy is safest option after intubation

questions.warning: PLANNED tracheostomy is ALWAYS better than EMERGENCY tracheostomy. Emergency situations lead to trauma, longer ICU stays, and worse outcomes. Prepare knowledge-wise and plan ahead.
questions.recommendation: For tracheostomy, talk to experienced members of the ALSCAS group, talk to as many caregivers as you want. Decision should be yours, your family's, and PALS's together.
perspectives: Tracheostomy need arises when PALS become 24x7 dependent on BiPAP, the normal airway has become weaker, plus they are unable to maintain saturation even with BiPAP ‚Äî then tracheostomy is a must.
As per our experience we can go for Tracheostomy when PALS is 24x7 on BiPAP plus still feeling breathing difficulty.
Less than 90 with BiPAP - time to consider Tracheostomy. It would be great relief to PALS but requires lot of time and financial commitment from CALS.
Many PALS continue on NIV BiPAP for years with good secretion management and cough assist use.

questions.question: When should a PALS start using a feeding tube (PEG or Ryles)?
questions.answer:
The Same Logic as BiPAP Applies Here:

Early adaptation to feeding support is VERY important. Don't wait for emergencies.

Warning Signs That It's Time to Discuss Feeding Tube:

  1. Difficulty swallowing
  2. Coughing while eating or drinking
  3. Taking very long to finish meals
  4. Fear of eating due to difficulty
  5. Weight loss despite trying to eat
  6. Food going into windpipe (aspiration)
  7. Recurrent lung infections
Delaying Feeding TubeEarly Feeding Tube
Aspiration pneumonia riskProtected lungs
Malnutrition and weaknessMaintained nutrition
Each meal is traumaticStress-free nutrition
Emergency PEG (riskier)Planned PEG (safer)
PALS must be strong for procedureDone when PALS is stronger
üí¨ Important Clarification:
  • Having a feeding tube doesn't mean no oral eating
  • Many PALS continue to eat favorite foods by mouth for pleasure
  • Tube provides nutrition without the stress and risk
  • It's supplementary support, not a replacement for all oral intake


PEG Tube:When to Choose Which:
PEG: If long-term tube feeding expected
Ryles: If temporary or PALS not fit for PEG procedure
questions.warning: Repeated aspiration causes lung infections. Don't wait until emergency - aspiration pneumonia can be life-threatening.
questions.recommendation: If your PALS is taking more time per meal or facing difficulty swallowing or facing aspiration, start discussing feeding tube options with your doctor.

questions.question: What Nutrition is Best for ALS?
questions.answer:
Core Principles:

  • High Calorie: Needs are high! Aim for 2000-3000 calories/day to prevent weight loss from muscle wasting.
  • High Protein: Essential for muscle maintenance. Eggs, dal, paneer
  • Good Fats: Critical for energy. 2 teaspoons of ghee, coconut oil, or olive oil daily is beneficial.
  • Omega-3: May help slow progression (fish oil, flaxseeds).

Practical Tips:

  • Consistency: If swallowing is difficult, avoid thin liquids. Thicken everything.
  • Frequency: Multiple small meals are better than 3 large ones to reduce fatigue.

questions.question: How to thicken water for PALS with swallowing difficulty (dysphagia)?
questions.answer:
Why Thicken Liquids?

Water and thin liquids can be difficult to control because they move too quickly. For PALS with weakened swallowing muscles, thickened liquids slow down the flow and make swallowing easier and safer, reducing choking and aspiration risk.

When to Start Thickening:

  • Coughing or choking when drinking water
  • Feeling like liquids 'go down the wrong way'
  • Wet/gurgly voice after swallowing
  • Speech therapist recommends modified consistency

Community-Recommended Thickening Products:

1. Nestle Resource ThickenUp Clear (‚Çπ600-800)
'We have been using this quite effectively since last 6-8 months'
Clear, dissolves well without lumps, available on Amazon, Flipkart, medical stores.

2. Nature's Velvet Xanthan Gum Powder (‚Çπ400-500 for 500gms)
'I used it a couple of times'
Natural thickening agent, cost-effective alternative.

3. Thick-It (Imported) (‚Çπ1,200-1,800)
Well-known international brand, available on Amazon India.

Thickening LevelConsistencyDescription
Slightly ThickLike anti-reflux formulaFlows quickly
Mildly ThickLike lassiFlows slower
Moderately ThickLike honeyDrips slowly
Extremely ThickLike puddingHolds shape

Practical Tips:

  • Start small: Add thickener gradually, wait 1-2 mins for full effect
  • Mix properly: Use blender for lump-free consistency
  • Thicken all liquids: Water, tea, juice, dal, rasam
  • Carry when traveling: Keep small container ready
  • Check temperature: Hot liquids may need re-thickening after cooling

Community Wisdom:

'We thicken everything now. Even water for brushing teeth. It reduced his choking episodes significantly.'
'Initially he resisted because it tastes different. But after explaining the aspiration risk, he understood. Safety over taste.'
questions.recommendation: Consult a speech therapist to determine the right consistency level for your PALS. Monitor hydration as some PALS drink less due to texture change.

questions.question: Why do families delay BiPAP and feeding tube even after knowing the signs?
questions.answer:
The Emotional Reality Every CALS Faces:

We understand. We've been there. Here's what happens:

1. The Over-Positivity Trap:

  • We truly believe our PALS may never need these devices
  • 'Let's wait and see how it goes'
  • We interpret stable SpO‚ÇÇ as 'not needing support yet'
  • Accepting BiPAP feels like accepting disease progression

2. We Wait for Doctors to Decide:

  • We think doctors will tell us when it's time
  • But doctors without ALS experience often don't know
  • They see normal SpO‚ÇÇ and say 'wait'
  • We miss the window for early intervention

3. Fear of Making PALS Dependent:

  • We think using support will make muscles weaker
  • THIS IS THE OPPOSITE OF REALITY
  • In ALS, the less fatigue = the better
  • Early support PRESERVES muscle function

The Hindsight Perspective (From Those Who've Been Through It):

Community Voices:

'We were on the other side of the picture and made the same mistake. Things look easy when reading these messages, but when you're living it, you're sometimes over-positive. You think your PALS will never need this and fail to realize the importance of early use.'
'She was walking until admitted to ICU. Now bedridden. If PEG was done earlier, it may not have happened. We kept delaying because she could still eat slowly.'
'Cough assist machine would have postponed my father's tracheostomy. We didn't know.'
The Mindset Shift Needed:
Think of BiPAP and feeding tube as TOOLS FOR QUALITY OF LIFE, not as signs of defeat. Early use = more good days, fewer emergencies, preserved strength, and precious time.

questions.question: How to Deal with Hospital Staff Ignorance?
questions.answer:
The Reality of Care:

Many doctors and nursing staff, outside of specialized neurologists, may lack specific knowledge about ALS/MND care protocols. Hospitals are often understaffed, and standard protocols can sometimes be harmful for ALS patients (e.g., giving high-flow oxygen without BiPAP).

Community Wisdom:

  • Educate Yourself: You must become the expert. Learn from the ALSCAS website and experienced community members.
  • Confront if Needed: Be prepared to politely but firmly question wrong practices (like using CPAP instead of BiPAP).
  • Home is Safe Haven: Bring PALS home as soon as they are stable. Home ICU setups often provide more focused and safer care than general hospital wards.
  • Train Your Team: Don't rely solely on hospital nurses. Train your own home attendants and family members.
üí¨ Community Insight:
'The neurologists, pulmonologists, ICU doctors do not have knowledge about this disease and they want to just blindly follow protocols. The only way is we need to educate ourselves and confront.'

questions.question: What essential equipment should we have at home as ALS progresses?
questions.answer:
Staged Equipment Guide Based on Community Experience:

üîµ EARLY STAGE Equipment:

  • Mobility aids (walker, walking stick)
  • Shower chair and bathroom grab bars
  • Elevated toilet seat
  • Non-slip mats throughout home
  • Simple home modifications (remove rugs, clear pathways)

üü° MID STAGE Equipment:

  • Wheelchair (manual or electric based on arm strength)
  • Hospital-style bed with adjustable height
  • Portable suction machine (for saliva management)
  • Communication aids (alphabet board, eye gaze device)
  • Air mattress or pressure-relieving mattress

üî¥ ADVANCED STAGE Equipment (Have BEFORE Needed!):

  • BiPAP machine - DON'T WAIT! Get when early signs appear
  • Pulse oximeter - Monitor SpO‚ÇÇ regularly
  • Cough assist machine - Helps clear secretions
  • Feeding tube supplies (if using PEG/Ryles)
  • UPS/Inverter/Generator - CRITICAL for power backup
  • Ambu bag - Manual resuscitation for emergencies

‚ö´ FOR TRACHEOSTOMY CARE:

  • Portable suction machine (MUST have)
  • Tracheostomy supplies (cannulas, dressing)
  • Humidifier for ventilator
  • Backup ventilator circuits

üí° Community Pro Tips:

  1. Power backup is NON-NEGOTIABLE:
    'We almost lost our father during a power cut. Now we have UPS + inverter + generator.'
    Invest in reliable UPS (‚Çπ15,000-30,000 for good quality)
  2. Get BiPAP BEFORE you need it:
    Rental first to try, then buy
    Having it at home reduces emergency hospital visits
  3. Cough assist is underrated:
    'Cough assist machine would have postponed my father's tracheostomy'
    Cost: ‚Çπ1.5-3 lakhs, but worth it
  4. Second suction machine:
    Keep one portable for travel/emergencies
    Always have backup

üáÆüá≥ Budget Considerations:
Start with essentials, add as needed. Many items available on rental (BiPAP, hospital bed). Some NGOs provide equipment support. Second-hand equipment from other CALS families (check groups).
questions.recommendation: Don't wait to buy equipment until emergency. Plan ahead based on progression stage. Rent first, then decide if purchase makes sense.

questions.question: How do I manage if there is a power cut while PALS is on BiPAP or ventilator?
questions.answer:
THIS IS A LIFE-THREATENING SITUATION - Prepare BEFORE It Happens!

Backup LevelEquipmentRun TimeCost (‚Çπ)
Level 1UPS with extra batteries30-60 mins15,000-30,000
Level 2Inverter with batteries3-6 hours25,000-50,000
Level 3Generator (petrol/diesel)Unlimited30,000-80,000

Recommended Setup:

  • UPS for immediate switch (no gap in power)
  • Inverter for medium outages
  • Generator for extended outages
  • ALL THREE if PALS is ventilator-dependent

Emergency Protocol During Power Cut:

  1. First 10 seconds: UPS should auto-switch
  2. Check BiPAP/ventilator is running
  3. If NOT running: Start manual Ambu bag immediately
  4. Within 5 minutes: Start generator if inverter insufficient
  5. Call for help if you cannot manage alone

Manual Ventilation with Ambu Bag:

  • MUST know how to use BEFORE emergency
  • Practice with respiratory therapist
  • Keep Ambu bag near PALS at all times
  • One squeeze = one breath (match normal breathing rate)

Real Stories:

‚ö†Ô∏è 'We almost lost our father during power cut. The inverter wasn't charged. Now we have triple backup.'
‚úÖ 'Every night I check UPS charge level. Peace of mind is priceless.'
‚ö†Ô∏è 'Generator didn't start because we never tested it. Always run your generator once a week!'

Pro Tips:

  • Test all backup equipment WEEKLY
  • Keep generator fuel stocked
  • Have electrician's number handy
  • Inform your electricity board that you have a ventilator patient
  • Some areas give priority power restoration for medical cases

üáÆüá≥ India-Specific:
Electricity boards have provisions for medical cases. Apply for priority power restoration. Some states waive/reduce electricity charges for ventilator patients.
questions.warning: Power backup is CRITICAL. Test regularly. A ventilator patient cannot wait even 2 minutes without power or manual ventilation.

questions.question: What Equipment Should We Have at Home? (A Staged Guide)
questions.answer:
Stage 1: Early (Buy Before Needed)

  • Pulse Oximeter & BP Monitor: Daily vitals tracking.
  • BiPAP Machine: The lifeline. Get it early.
  • Walker & AFO: For foot drop and mobility support.

Stage 2: Intermediate

  • Oxygen Concentrator (5L): Backup for emergencies.
  • Suction Machine: Crucial for saliva management.
  • Nebulizer: For clearing congestion.
  • Cough Assist Machine: To clear lungs.
  • Wheelchair & Hoyer Lift: For safe transfers.

Stage 3: Advanced (Home ICU)

  • Ventilator (Trilogy/Astral): Plus a backup device.
  • Hospital Bed: Electric with elevation.
  • Air Mattress: To prevent bedsores.
  • Eye Tracker (Tobii): Only communication lifeline.
  • Power Backup: Generator or heavy-duty UPS (Critical!).
  • Ambu Bag: Manual resuscitation for power failures.

questions.question: How to Set Up a 'Home ICU'?
questions.answer:
Why Home ICU?

Experienced families find that a well-equipped Home ICU is often safer and more comfortable than a hospital, reducing infection risk and allowing 24x7 personalized care.

Essential Setup Checklist:

  • Respiratory: Ventilator/BiPAP (+ backup), Oxygen concentrator (+ cylinder backup), Suction machine, Cough assist.
  • Monitoring: Multipara monitor (SpO2, HR, BP).
  • Comfort: Hospital bed (5-function preferred), Alpha air mattress.
  • Safety: Ambu bag (manual ventilator), emergency IV antibiotics/meds kit.
  • Power: DEDICATED UPS for medical equipment + Generator backup.
  • Staffing: Trained 24x7 nursing/caregiver support.

What Actually Works (Community Wisdom):

  • 'Physiotherapy works 100%.'
  • 'Speech therapy and breathing exercises work.'
  • 'Excessive food intake is a must.'
  • 'Early adoption of BiPAP and PEG is important.'

questions.question: How do I manage excessive saliva and secretions in ALS?
questions.answer:
Secretion Management - A Daily Challenge for Many CALS:

Why Secretions Increase in ALS:

  • Swallowing muscles weaken
  • Cannot swallow saliva normally
  • Saliva pools in mouth and throat
  • NOT increased saliva production, just reduced clearing

Management Strategies:

1. Positioning:
Keep head slightly elevated. Side-lying position helps drainage. Avoid flat lying (increases pooling).

2. Suctioning:
Portable suction machine (‚Çπ5,000-15,000). Learn proper technique from nurse. Don't suction too deep (causes trauma). Clean suction equipment daily.

3. Medications (Consult Doctor):
Glycopyrrolate - Reduces secretions
Atropine drops under tongue
Scopolamine patches
Note: These can thicken secretions

4. Hydration:
Adequate water intake keeps secretions thin. Dehydration makes secretions thick and difficult.

5. Nebulization:
Saline nebulization helps thin secretions. Can be done 2-3 times daily.

Community Tips:

'We use a small handheld suction for quick clearing. The big machine is by the bed for nights.'
'Glycopyrrolate worked for us, but made his mouth very dry. We balance with humidifier.'
'Thick secretions are harder to clear. We ensure he drinks enough water (through tube if needed).'

For Tracheostomy Patients:
More frequent suctioning needed. Keep humidity in room. Saline drops before suctioning helps. Watch for color changes (yellow/green = infection).

Warning Signs (Consult Doctor):
Green/yellow secretions (possible infection), Blood in secretions, Sudden increase in secretions, Fever with increased secretions
